description: The Syrian government ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2.
type: Closure and Regulation of Schools
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: The Syrian government ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2.
type: Closure and Regulation of Schools
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: The Syrian government originally ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2 but has decided to extend this on May 6 and reopen universities and institutions as of May 31, 2020. UPDATE: The Syrian government originally ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2 but decided on Wednesday, 6 May to extend this reopen universities and institutions as of May 31, 2020.
type: Closure and Regulation of Schools
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: The Syrian government originally ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2 but has decided to extend this on May 6 and reopen universities and institutions as of May 31, 2020. UPDATE: The Syrian government originally ordered the closure of universities, schools and institutions from March 14 to April 2 but decided on Wednesday, 6 May to extend this reopen universities and institutions as of May 31, 2020.
type: Closure and Regulation of Schools
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: On March 20, the government banned entry for foreigners, after the first coronavirus victim reached Syria by road from Lebanon after returning from Europe.
type: External Border Restrictions
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description: Health officials have deployed medical teams at the national level and to 1,864 health clinics across the country.
type: Health Resources
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: The Syrian Government decided on a curfew to prevent the movement of citizens between centres of cities and countryside which came into effect on the 31st of March and is set to last until the 16th of April.
type: Internal Border Restrictions
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
The Syrian Interior Ministry extended the curfew among provinces which prevents the commuting of citizens between province centres and all other urban and rural areas at all times excluding those with clearance 
set to last until April 16 to May 2nd. UPDATE: The original travel restriction referred to under the curfew measure by the Syrian government set to last until April 16 has been extended to May 2.
type: Internal Border Restrictions
type_sub_cat: NA

description: The Syrian Government with the curfew still in place until May 2nd has decided to allow citizens to travel among provinces on the 20th and 21st of April after putting medical teams at the entrance of each province. UPDATE: Curfew among provinces is still enforced until May 2 but the government is making an exception and allowing citizens to travel among provinces on the 20th and 21st of April.
type: Internal Border Restrictions
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On March 23, the government stepped up procedures for the supposed response to the epidemic by carrying out campaigns to sterilize cities and villages.
type: Other Policy Not Listed Above
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Syrian Health Ministry launched a service on its website which shows the distribution of registered Coronavirus cases in Syria, sorting them by provinces, age groups, gender, and cause of infection. The service also contains information on the 5 official labs that conduct COVID-19 tests, and the centers for quarantine and isolation.
type: Public Awareness Measures
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 18, the Recruitment Directorate affiliated with the Syria regime forces announced the suspension of the issuance of driver's licenses and military service completion attestations until April 22.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
